paragraphs.text: Group related information

Life is short. No one wants to fill out a form. Be conversational. Be funny. Gradually engage. Do the unexpected. It is the role of the designer to express their company’s brand to elicit an emotional reaction. If done correctly, it will increase completion rates. Just make sure you don’t violate the rules listed above.
paragraphs.name: 8d58

paragraphs.text: Omit optional fields and think of other ways to collect data. Always ask yourself if the question can be inferred, postponed, or completely excluded.
paragraphs.name: d822

bdf1d30e562f.title: A dropdown is one of the most recognized, universal paradigms.

paragraphs.text: A dropdown is one of the most recognized, universal paradigms. Why choose to break that pattern even if its under 6 options? The issue I am seeing with your recommended solution is the design may suggest that I can select multiple options like Bear and Tiger, when in fact I can only select one. In the drop down option, its clear I can only select one…
paragraphs.name: 874c

ee5b998a9bd8.title: Designing forms isn’t the sexiest job but we all end up doing it.

paragraphs.text: Designing forms isn’t the sexiest job but we all end up doing it. Might as well make sure they work as intended. This is great info, thanks.

5d6ec0691be6.title: Okey, I don’t see “left aligned lables” wrong in all situations.

paragraphs.text: Okey, I don’t see “left aligned lables” wrong in all situations. There are many cases where this scenario is a solution.
Useful summary. I literally just finished compiling a list for my client like this. You could have published this last week ;)
paragraphs.name: be41

paragraphs.text: Nicely delivered. I can appreciate solid, well-articulated dos and don’ts with relevant examples. Thanks, genuinely… A two minute read that comes with a permanently improved skillset is indeed hard to find.
Great advice! Andrew Coyle, wouldn’t you replace the Verify password field for a toggleable “show password” option? Thank you!

fa6a997cdaae.title: All great tips but I usually take this one further and split them into separate screens to aid the…

paragraphs.text: All great tips but I usually take this one further and split them into separate screens to aid the journey. If validation occurs you have to scroll through the entire page. GDS have done lots of research in this area https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/user-centred-design/resources/patterns/form-structure.html#section-3
paragraphs.name: 05a3

f413a0a5931b.title: I find these “do” and “don’t do” design posts to be dangerous.

paragraphs.text: I find these “do” and “don’t do” design posts to be dangerous. What data are you using to come up with these hard and fast rules about which input style is better? We’ve run AB tests on large sample sizes with results that are counter to what you’re recommending to people.

paragraphs.text: This is a great list. I think, though, that it’s important to cite case studies that back up all or each of these points if possible. There’s a handy link to Nielsen Norman Group on using placeholder as labels (which in turn provides quantitative data and links to relevant research), but this is for one of many points.

paragraphs.text: If you have something like “Terrible,” “Below Average,” “Average”, “Above Average,” and “Amazing,” you are going to quickly be fighting horizontal space limitations, especially on smaller screen sizes.
